question.title: How to efficiently check Gradle build cache status without executing tasks?
question.body:
I'm running a GitLab CI pipeline with 30+ tests in parallel, each taking 5-10 minutes. I've configured Gradle to use build cache, which works great when tests need to run.

However, even when a test is cached, the GitLab runner still takes ~4 minutes to start up and determine the cache status. This seems inefficient as we're spinning up runners just to find out we don't need them.

Is there a way to query Gradle's build cache status for a task without actually executing the task or its setup? The --dry-run option doesn't show cache status information.

I'm looking for something like:

gradle someCommand --check-cache-only myTest

This would help optimize our CI pipeline by avoiding unnecessary runner startups.

question_comments.body: Unfortunately, Gradle doesn’t offer a built‐in way to just “check” the cache for a task without going through the task’s execution lifecycle. The cache lookup is integrated into the task’s execution phase, which is why even a cached task still goes through some of the startup and setup work.
